FCT and VAT implications
Overview of Vietnamese taxation
Foreign Contractor Tax (“FCT”) is a comprehensive tax collection regime that applies to, amongst others, foreign business organizations, with or without permanent establishment (“PE”) in Vietnam, doing business in Vietnam or having Vietnam-sourced income on the basis of a contract, agreement or undertaking with Vietnamese organizations. Broadly, FCT is a collection mechanism for Corporate Income Tax (“CIT”) and Value Add Tax (“VAT”).
Conceptually, FCT will not be applied if the goods are supplied with the place of delivery at the border gates, and without accompanied services provided in Vietnam.

The risk of exposing to income tax of this flash-title-transfer transaction, therefore, is considered high.
There is no clear mechanism on how to declare and pay taxes on this type of transactions under the current tax regulations. However, the taxing mechanism was guided/mentioned under the above OLs;
In practice, the policy makers are becoming well aware of this kind of business model and may insist to tax by carrying out tax audits at the bonded warehouse management or the logistics companies, on the basis that the bonded warehouse managers are required to notify the Customs Office regarding the transfer of ownership of goods stored at the bonded warehouse for management and supervision under the Customs regulations.2
The “substance over form principle” was enacted under the Law on Tax Administration 2019 which is effective from 01 July 2020, being the principle applied in tax administration to analyze transactions and business activities of taxpayers to determine the corresponding tax obligations.3
Given the above, the absence of taxing mechanism would not reduce the level of tax risk since (i) the transaction is taxable in principle and (ii) a number of OLs have confirmed taxing mechanism in practice. Since the responsibilities to withhold, declare and pay taxes rests with income payment organization (i.e.
Client TW) in practice, it is recommended that a private ruling should be obtained from the local tax authorities to confirm the tax position of the transaction and the mechanism to declare and pay taxes in Vietnam.

Where ABC sends a number of expatriates to perform services in Vietnam continuously over a number of years with the residing days of each expatriate being 182 days or more in any calendar year from 2021, referring to the above mentioned three conditions of PE constitution, it is likely that ABC would be deemed to carry out part of its business through a PE in Vietnam.
Per our observation of the local tax authority’s interpretation, as long as the PE of ABC is deemed to exist, the remuneration of the expatriates is likely to be considered as borne by the PE, under which circumstance, condition (c) is not satisfied.
The remuneration is subject to tax in Australia
We understand that this condition is met as the expatriates continue to be taxed as tax residents in Australia.
Based on the above analysis, the chance to claim PIT exemption in Vietnam under the DTA is considered to be low.
Tax credit
Where the tax exemption is not available under the DTAs, the double taxation can be eliminated by way of tax credit (provided for under Article 23 of the DTA), according to which, tax paid in Australia can be credited against tax payable by the expatriates in Vietnam if they are Vietnamese tax residents. The creditable tax amount, however, shall not exceed the amount of the Vietnamese tax computed in accordance with Vietnamese tax regulations.
Alternatively, the tax paid in Vietnam may also be allowed to be credited against any Australian tax computed on the same income, subject to the provisions of the laws of Australia where the expatriates are considered as tax residents of Australia
It is noted that where tax credit under DTA is applied, it should be applied in one country only, i.e. either Vietnam or Australia, not both.
Income from capital gain/dividends
According to Article 10 of the DTA, dividends paid by an Australian resident company to a Vietnamese resident individual can be taxed in both countries but the tax so charged shall not exceed 10% of the gross amount of the dividends in Vietnam and 15% in Australia. Whereas the tax rate for dividend under Vietnamese PIT regulations is only 5%, applying DTA does not offer any tax relief for this kind of income from Vietnam perspective;

Tax exemption
Under the current Vietnamese tax regulations, where Vietnam enters into a DTA with a contracting country, provisions agreed under the DTA will prevail in cases where differences exist between the domestic laws and the DTA. For the contemplated capital transfer, Vietnam – Singapore DTA and Vietnam – the UK DTA and might be referred to respectively.
Possibility for tax exemption under Vietnam – Singapore DTA
Pursuant to Paragraph 4, Article 13 (Capital gains) of Vietnam – Singapore DTA which was amended by Article VII, Announcement No. 05/2013/TB-LPQT:
“Gains derived by a resident of a Contracting State from the alienation of shares, other than shares of a company posted on a recognized stock exchange of one or both Contracting States, deriving more than 50% of their value directly or indirectly from immovable property situated in the other Contracting State may be taxed in that other State.”
That said, under Vietnam - Singapore DTA, as THE VIETNAMESE COMPANY’s shares are not posted on a recognized stock exchange of both Vietnam and Singapore, gain from capital transfer will be taxed in Vietnam if THE VIETNAMESE COMPANY’s assets consist, directly or indirectly, more than 50% of immovable property situated in Vietnam (i.e. the ratio of immovable property).
Regarding the calculation of the ratio of immovable properties of THE VIETNAMESE COMPANY:
In accordance with Point 4, Article 27, Circular 205/2013/TT-BTC dated 24 December 2013 of Ministry of Finance, providing the guidance on the DTA implementation regarding the capital transfer:
“Ratio of immovable property value in total properties of enterprise is simple average of ratios of immovable property value in total properties of enterprise at time of transfer of property, the beginning time and ending time of tax year prior to year when the shares are transferred. Determination of immovable property value is based on the audited summary of properties of enterprise at the aforesaid times.
The principal ratio of immovable property value in total properties of enterprise is determined as follows: “… Where Agreement specifies the rate or principal rate, complying with the rate prescribed in Agreement”.
We hereafter present our approach to determine the value of immovable property as follows:
Pursuant to Clause 2, Article 6 of the Vietnam – Singapore DTA, the term "immovable property" shall have the meaning which it has under the law of the Contracting State in which the property in question is situated.
Pursuant to Circular 205, in the case of Vietnam, immovable property includes:
Types of assets as stipulated under definition of immovable property of Civil Code and Law on Real Estate Trading;
Sub-assets attached to these aforementioned assets;
Livestock and equipment used in agriculture and forestry;
Rights applied under law on land in Vietnam; 
Rights to enjoy payments for the natural resource exploitation or the right to exploit natural resources.
